description: Canadian Residential Mortgage Underwriting Policies - OSFI B-20 Guidelines for mortgage underwriting including debt service ratios, stress testing, income qualification, and risk assessment

policies.name: Gross Debt Service Ratio Limit
policies.description: Maximum GDS ratio for mortgage qualification per OSFI B-20

criteria.action: Application meets GDS requirements. Proceed with assessment.
criteria.rationale: GDS (Gross Debt Service) ratio within OSFI B-20 limit of 39%. Borrower can afford housing costs relative to income.

criteria.action: GDS slightly above limit. Review compensating factors: high credit score (>740), substantial down payment (>25%), stable employment (5+ years).
criteria.rationale: Minor GDS exceedance may be acceptable with strong compensating factors.

criteria.action: GDS significantly exceeds OSFI limit. DECLINE unless exceptional circumstances. Recommend: reduce purchase price, increase down payment, or reduce housing costs.
criteria.rationale: Excessive housing cost burden relative to income creates high default risk.

policies.calculation: GDS = (P + I + T + H + 50% of Condo Fees) / Gross Monthly Income

policies.name: Total Debt Service Ratio Limit
policies.description: Maximum TDS ratio for mortgage qualification per OSFI B-20

criteria.action: Application meets TDS requirements. Proceed with assessment.
criteria.rationale: TDS (Total Debt Service) ratio within OSFI B-20 limit of 44%. Borrower can afford total debt obligations relative to income.

criteria.action: TDS slightly above limit. Review compensating factors and consider debt consolidation or elimination of certain debts.
criteria.rationale: Minor TDS exceedance requires additional scrutiny of debt obligations.

criteria.action: TDS significantly exceeds OSFI limit. DECLINE. Recommend: pay down existing debts, reduce purchase price, or increase income.
criteria.rationale: Excessive total debt burden creates high risk of default and financial hardship.

policies.calculation: TDS = (PITH + Other Monthly Debts) / Gross Monthly Income

policies.name: Mortgage Qualifying Rate (MQR) Stress Test
policies.description: All uninsured mortgages must qualify at the Mortgage Qualifying Rate per OSFI B-20

criteria.condition: Application qualifies at MQR (contract rate + 2% OR 5.25%, whichever is greater)
criteria.action: Application passes stress test. Borrower can afford payments if rates increase.
criteria.rationale: OSFI B-20 requires stress testing to ensure borrowers can withstand interest rate increases.

criteria.condition: Application fails at MQR (GDS or TDS exceeds limits when using qualifying rate)
criteria.action: DECLINE. Application does not pass mandatory stress test. Recommend: reduce loan amount, increase down payment, or reduce other debts.
criteria.rationale: Stress test failure indicates borrower cannot withstand potential rate increases. Mandatory requirement per OSFI B-20.

policies.name: Conventional Mortgage LTV Limit
policies.description: Maximum LTV for conventional (uninsured) mortgages

criteria.action: LTV meets conventional mortgage requirements. No mortgage insurance required.
criteria.rationale: Down payment of at least 20% provides adequate equity cushion.

criteria.action: LTV exceeds conventional limit. Require CMHC/Genworth/Canada Guaranty mortgage insurance. Assess as high-ratio mortgage.
criteria.rationale: Down payment less than 20% requires default insurance per regulations.

criteria.action: LTV exceeds maximum insurable limit. DECLINE. Minimum 5% down payment required.
criteria.rationale: Canadian regulations require minimum 5% down payment on all mortgages.

policies.calculation: LTV = Loan Amount / Property Value (lesser of purchase price or appraisal)
references: Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation (CMHC) Guidelines

policies.name: Minimum Down Payment Requirements
policies.description: Graduated down payment requirements based on purchase price

criteria.action: Minimum 5% down payment required.
criteria.rationale: Standard minimum for homes under $500K.

criteria.action: Minimum down payment: 5% on first $500K + 10% on amount above $500K.
criteria.rationale: Graduated requirement for mid-priced homes.

criteria.action: Minimum 20% down payment required. Mortgage insurance not available.
criteria.rationale: Homes $1M+ must be uninsured conventional mortgages.

policies.name: Down Payment Source Verification
policies.description: Requirements for verifying and documenting down payment sources

criteria.condition: Down payment from savings (90-day history in bank statements)
criteria.action: Acceptable source. Verify with 90 days of bank statements showing accumulation.
criteria.rationale: Savings with established history demonstrate financial discipline.

criteria.condition: Down payment from gift (with signed gift letter)
criteria.action: Acceptable source. Require: signed gift letter stating no repayment required, proof of transfer, donor relationship verification.
criteria.rationale: Gifts from immediate family are acceptable with proper documentation.

criteria.condition: Down payment from RRSP (Home Buyers' Plan)
criteria.action: Acceptable source up to $35,000 per person ($70,000 for couple). Verify RRSP statements and HBP eligibility.
criteria.rationale: Home Buyers' Plan allows tax-free RRSP withdrawal for first-time buyers.

criteria.condition: Down payment from sale of property (with closing statement)
criteria.action: Acceptable source. Verify with signed agreement of purchase and sale, closing statement showing net proceeds.
criteria.rationale: Equity from property sale is standard down payment source.

criteria.condition: Down payment source unclear or suspicious (large recent deposits)
criteria.action: Request written explanation and supporting documentation for all large deposits in past 90 days. Flag for AML review if unexplained.
criteria.rationale: Large unexplained deposits may indicate loan proceeds, money laundering, or undisclosed debt.

policies.name: Salary Income Verification
policies.description: Requirements for verifying and qualifying salary income

criteria.condition: Permanent full-time employment (2+ years same employer OR 2+ years same industry)
criteria.action: Verify with: employment letter, 2 recent paystubs, 2 years T4s or NOAs. Use 100% of base salary.
criteria.rationale: Stable permanent employment with consistent income.

criteria.action: Require confirmation of successful probation completion before funding. Consider excluding or haircutting income.
criteria.rationale: Probationary employment has termination risk.

criteria.condition: Contract employment (renewable contracts with 1+ year remaining)
criteria.action: Verify with: signed contract showing end date, 2 years history of renewals, 2 years T4s or NOAs. Use 100% of contract income if renewal history strong.
criteria.rationale: Contract employment acceptable with history of renewals.

required_documents: Employment verification letter (signed by employer, on letterhead)
Most recent 2 years Notice of Assessment (NOA) from CRA

policies.name: Variable Income (Bonus, Commission, Overtime)
policies.description: Requirements for qualifying variable income components

criteria.condition: Bonus income (2+ year history shown on T4s)
criteria.action: Apply 50% haircut to 2-year average bonus income. Verify with T4s showing consistent bonus history.
criteria.rationale: Bonuses are discretionary and may not continue. 50% haircut provides conservative estimate.

criteria.action: Apply 50% haircut to 2-year average commission income. Verify with T4s and paystubs showing commission breakdown.
criteria.rationale: Commission income is variable and market-dependent. 50% haircut required.

criteria.action: Apply 50% haircut to 2-year average overtime income if consistently earned. Verify with T4s and paystubs.
criteria.rationale: Overtime is not guaranteed and may be reduced. 50% haircut required.

criteria.condition: Variable income < 1 year history OR declining trend
criteria.action: Exclude from qualifying income. Recent or declining variable income is not reliable.
criteria.rationale: Insufficient history or negative trend makes income unreliable.

policies.name: Self-Employed Income
policies.description: Requirements for qualifying self-employed borrowers

criteria.action: Use 2-year average of Line 150 (Total Income) from T1 General + addbacks (depreciation, CCA). Verify with: 2 years complete T1 + NOAs, current Interim Financial Statement if > 6 months since year-end.
criteria.rationale: 2-year average smooths income fluctuations. Addbacks restore non-cash expenses.

criteria.action: Refer to senior underwriter. Consider declining if no extenuating circumstances. Insufficient business track record.
criteria.rationale: New businesses and declining income present high risk.

criteria.action: Treat as employed income if ownership < 25%. Require employment letter from business and T4.
criteria.rationale: Minority ownership treated as employment rather than self-employment.

required_documents: Complete T1 General (all pages) for most recent 2 years
Notice of Assessment (NOA) for most recent 2 years
Articles of Incorporation or Business License
Interim Financial Statement (if > 6 months since year-end)
policies.income_calculation: Average of (Line 150 + Depreciation + CCA) for 2 years

policies.name: Rental Income
policies.description: Requirements for qualifying rental income from investment properties

criteria.condition: Rental property owned 2+ years (positive cash flow)
criteria.action: Use 50% of gross monthly rent (net of vacancy and expense allowance). Verify with: signed lease agreement, 2 years rental history on T1 (T776), property tax bill.
criteria.rationale: 50% offset accounts for vacancy, maintenance, and operating expenses.

criteria.condition: Proposed rental income (property will be rented)
criteria.action: Use 50% of appraised rental value (from appraisal comparables). Do NOT use for subject property if purchased as primary residence.
criteria.rationale: Proposed rental income requires conservative treatment.

criteria.condition: Subject property basement suite or secondary unit
criteria.action: Exclude unless: suite is legal/permitted, separate entrance, 2+ year history of rental. Maximum 30% of qualifying income from rental.
criteria.rationale: Basement suite income is less reliable. Require legal status and history.

policies.name: Maximum Amortization Periods
policies.description: Maximum allowable amortization periods per OSFI B-20

criteria.action: Maximum 25-year amortization. Longer amortization not available for insured mortgages.
criteria.rationale: CMHC limits insured mortgages to 25-year amortization to reduce default risk.

criteria.action: Maximum 30-year amortization. Longer periods increase payment affordability but total interest cost.
criteria.rationale: Conventional mortgages may have up to 30-year amortization.

criteria.action: DECLINE. Maximum 30-year amortization per regulations.
criteria.rationale: Amortization beyond 30 years not permitted in Canada.

policies.name: Fraud Risk Signals
policies.description: Red flags that may indicate mortgage fraud

criteria.condition: Income documentation inconsistencies (paystub vs T4 vs employment letter)
criteria.action: REFER to fraud team. Contact employer directly to verify employment and income. May indicate forged documents.
criteria.rationale: Income inconsistencies are primary indicator of application fraud.

criteria.action: Request additional documentation. Verify income directly with employer.
criteria.rationale: Legitimate income rarely falls on exact round numbers.

criteria.condition: Property flip (purchased < 1 year ago at significantly lower price)
criteria.action: Require independent appraisal. Investigate prior sale details. If price increased >20% in < 1 year, refer for review.
criteria.rationale: Rapid appreciation may indicate property value fraud or straw buyer scheme.

criteria.action: Require independent appraisal. Verify transaction is at fair market value. Document relationship.
criteria.rationale: Related party transactions may overstate property value.

criteria.condition: Employment verification fails (employer does not confirm employment/income)
criteria.action: DECLINE. Do not proceed without verified employment.
criteria.rationale: Inability to verify employment indicates forged documentation.

policies.name: Anti-Money Laundering (AML) Risk Signals
policies.description: Indicators requiring enhanced due diligence for AML compliance

criteria.condition: Large cash deposits (>$10,000) in past 90 days
criteria.action: Require written explanation and source documentation. Report to FINTRAC if suspicious. Do not use unexplained cash for down payment.
criteria.rationale: Large cash deposits may indicate proceeds of crime or money laundering.

criteria.condition: Structured deposits (multiple deposits just under $10,000 reporting threshold)
criteria.action: REFER to compliance. Structuring to avoid reporting is illegal. File Suspicious Transaction Report (STR) with FINTRAC.
criteria.rationale: Structuring is a criminal offense indicating deliberate avoidance of reporting.

criteria.condition: Down payment from foreign source (wire transfer from non-Canadian bank)
criteria.action: Verify source of funds. Require documentation: foreign bank statements, employment verification, tax returns from source country. Enhanced due diligence required.
criteria.rationale: Foreign source funds require additional scrutiny for AML compliance.

criteria.condition: Borrower is PEP (Politically Exposed Person) or close associate
criteria.action: Enhanced due diligence required. Verify source of wealth and funds. Senior approval required.
criteria.rationale: PEPs present higher risk of corruption or money laundering per FINTRAC.

references: Proceeds of Crime (Money Laundering) and Terrorist Financing Act

policies.name: Property Occupancy Type
policies.description: Risk assessment based on intended property occupancy

criteria.condition: Owner-occupied (borrower will live in property as principal residence)
criteria.action: Lowest risk category. Standard underwriting applies.
criteria.rationale: Owner-occupied properties have lowest default rates.

criteria.action: Higher risk. May require higher down payment (10-15% minimum). Verify borrower can afford both properties.
criteria.rationale: Second homes present higher default risk. Borrowers may prioritize principal residence.

criteria.action: Higher risk. Minimum 20% down payment required (no insurance available). Verify rental income potential and borrower experience.
criteria.rationale: Investment properties have higher default rates and no insurance option.

criteria.action: REFER. Investigate stated vs actual occupancy. Occupancy fraud is common to obtain better rates.
criteria.rationale: Misrepresenting occupancy to obtain lower rates or insurance is fraud.

policies.name: Credit Score Requirements
policies.description: Minimum credit score requirements and risk tiers

criteria.action: Excellent credit. Lowest risk tier. May qualify for preferred rates.
criteria.rationale: High credit score indicates strong payment history and low default risk.

criteria.action: Good credit. Standard risk tier. Standard rates apply.
criteria.rationale: Good credit score with acceptable risk profile.

criteria.action: Fair credit. May require compensating factors: higher down payment, lower ratios, stable employment. May incur rate premium.
criteria.rationale: Fair credit requires additional scrutiny and risk mitigation.

criteria.action: Subprime tier. Refer to specialized lending. Significant rate premium. Minimum 20% down payment typically required.
criteria.rationale: Elevated credit risk requires specialized underwriting.

criteria.action: DECLINE for prime lending. Refer to alternative/private lenders if requested.
criteria.rationale: Credit score below acceptable threshold for prime mortgage lending.

policies.name: Derogatory Credit Items
policies.description: Treatment of derogatory credit events

criteria.condition: Bankruptcy discharged > 2 years ago (clean credit since)
criteria.action: May consider with: strong compensating factors, 20%+ down payment, clean credit for 2+ years post-discharge, written explanation.
criteria.rationale: Discharged bankruptcy with re-established credit may be acceptable.

criteria.action: May consider with: strong compensating factors, 20%+ down payment, clean credit for 2+ years post-completion.
criteria.rationale: Completed proposal with re-established credit may be acceptable.

criteria.condition: Recent late payments (within 12 months) on mortgage or rent
criteria.action: DECLINE unless isolated incident with strong explanation (medical emergency, job loss with quick recovery).
criteria.rationale: Recent housing payment delinquency is strong predictor of future default.

criteria.action: Require payment in full or settlement prior to funding. Obtain proof of payment/settlement.
criteria.rationale: Unpaid collections indicate unwillingness or inability to meet obligations.

criteria.action: Must be paid in full and discharged prior to funding. Cannot close with liens on property or borrower.
criteria.rationale: Liens must be cleared to obtain clear title.

policies.name: First-Time Home Buyer Incentive (FTHBI)
policies.description: CMHC shared equity program for first-time home buyers

criteria.condition: First-time buyer, household income <= $120,000 (or $150,000 in Toronto, Vancouver, Victoria)
criteria.action: Eligible for FTHBI. Government provides 5% (existing) or 10% (new construction) shared equity. Purchase price limit: 4x income (4.5x in high-cost markets).
criteria.rationale: FTHBI reduces monthly payments by sharing equity with government.

criteria.action: Not eligible for FTHBI. Proceed with standard mortgage assessment.
criteria.rationale: Income exceeds FTHBI program limits.

criteria.action: Inform borrower: FTHBI equity must be repaid at sale or after 25 years, whichever is first. Repayment = same percentage of property's fair market value at time of repayment.
criteria.rationale: Borrower shares property appreciation with government.

references: CMHC First-Time Home Buyer Incentive Program

policies.name: First Home Savings Account (FHSA)
policies.description: Tax-advantaged savings account for first-time home buyers

criteria.condition: Down payment from FHSA (with account statements)
criteria.action: Acceptable source. Verify with FHSA statements. Contributions are tax-deductible and withdrawals for home purchase are tax-free. Maximum $40,000 lifetime contribution.
criteria.rationale: FHSA provides tax-advantaged savings specifically for home purchase.

criteria.condition: Combined FHSA and RRSP HBP withdrawal
criteria.action: Acceptable combination. FHSA: up to $40,000 (tax-free withdrawal). HBP: up to $35,000 (repayable over 15 years). Total possible: $75,000 per person.
criteria.rationale: Both programs can be used together for larger down payment.

policies.name: Ontario Land Transfer Tax Rebate
policies.description: First-time home buyer rebate for Ontario land transfer tax

criteria.action: Eligible for Ontario LTT rebate up to $4,000. Reduces closing costs. Must occupy as principal residence within 9 months.
criteria.rationale: Provincial rebate reduces closing costs for first-time buyers.

criteria.action: Subject to BOTH Ontario LTT and Toronto Municipal LTT. First-time buyers eligible for rebates on both: up to $4,000 provincial + up to $4,475 municipal = $8,475 total.
criteria.rationale: Toronto has additional municipal land transfer tax.

references: City of Toronto Land Transfer Tax

policies.name: BC First Time Home Buyers' Program
policies.description: Property transfer tax exemption for BC first-time buyers

criteria.action: Full exemption from BC Property Transfer Tax. Saves up to $8,000. Must be Canadian citizen/PR, BC resident for 12 months.
criteria.rationale: Full PTT exemption for qualifying first-time buyers.

criteria.action: Partial exemption from BC Property Transfer Tax. Exemption phases out between $500K-$525K.
criteria.rationale: Partial exemption for properties slightly above threshold.

criteria.action: No first-time buyer PTT exemption. Full property transfer tax applies (1% on first $200K, 2% on $200K-$2M, 3% above $2M).
criteria.rationale: Property exceeds first-time buyer program limits.

criteria.action: Subject to BC Foreign Buyers Tax (20% additional PTT in Metro Vancouver, Victoria, Nanaimo, etc.). Verify residency status carefully.
criteria.rationale: Significant additional tax for non-residents. Verify eligibility for exemptions.

references: BC First Time Home Buyers' Program

policies.name: Quebec First-Time Home Buyer Programs
policies.description: Quebec-specific programs and welcome tax considerations

criteria.action: No provincial first-time buyer rebate on welcome tax (droit de mutation). Some municipalities offer rebates. Check local programs.
criteria.rationale: Quebec welcome tax rebates vary by municipality.

criteria.action: First-time buyers may qualify for Montreal Home Ownership Program. Provides up to $15,000 for down payment or renovations for properties needing work.
criteria.rationale: Montreal offers assistance for first-time buyers in certain conditions.

policies.name: Alberta Mortgage Programs
policies.description: Alberta-specific considerations including no land transfer tax

criteria.action: Alberta has NO provincial land transfer tax. Only registration fees apply (approx. $50 + $2 per $5,000 of property value). Lower closing costs than Ontario/BC.
criteria.rationale: Alberta's absence of LTT significantly reduces closing costs.

policies.name: Newcomers to Canada Mortgage Program
policies.description: Modified qualification criteria for recent immigrants

criteria.condition: Newcomer (landed immigrant or work permit holder) < 5 years in Canada
criteria.action: May qualify with 10% down payment (vs 20% for limited credit history). Require: valid work permit or PR card, employment letter, 3 months bank statements, credit reference from home country if available.
criteria.rationale: Special programs accommodate limited Canadian credit history.

criteria.condition: Newcomer with no Canadian credit history
criteria.action: Cannot obtain Canadian credit score. Require alternative documentation: 12 months rent payment history, foreign credit report (translated), utility payment history, employment stability evidence.
criteria.rationale: Alternative credit assessment required when no bureau score available.

criteria.action: Higher risk category. Minimum 35% down payment typically required. May not qualify for insured mortgages. Limited lender options.
criteria.rationale: Non-residents present higher risk due to enforcement challenges.

policies.name: Mortgage Portability Assessment
policies.description: Assessment of mortgage portability for property changes

criteria.condition: Borrower selling and buying within lender's portability window (30-120 days)
criteria.action: Mortgage may be portable to new property without penalty. Verify: same or lower mortgage amount, new property qualifies, timing requirements met.
criteria.rationale: Portability avoids prepayment penalty when moving.

criteria.condition: New property requires higher mortgage than existing
criteria.action: Port and blend option: existing mortgage ported + new funds at current rate. Blended rate calculated on weighted average. Re-qualification required for total amount.
criteria.rationale: Blend extends mortgage while preserving existing rate on ported portion.

modifying_factors.factor: High credit score (>780) with substantial liquid assets
modifying_factors.impact: May allow GDS/TDS ratios up to 2% higher than standard limits
May be eligible for CMHC First-Time Home Buyer Incentive, FHSA, provincial rebates
May have limited credit history. Require alternative documentation: foreign credit report, employment letter, bank statements from country of origin. May qualify for newcomer programs with 10% down.
High down payment (>25%), excellent credit (>760), stable long-term employment (10+ years), low existing debts
BC/Ontario have significant land transfer taxes. Toronto has municipal LTT. Alberta has no LTT. Factor into closing costs.
May require Business for Self (BFS) stated income program with higher down payment (typically 20%+)

glossary.GDS: Gross Debt Service - Housing costs (PITH) as percentage of gross income
glossary.TDS: Total Debt Service - Total debt obligations as percentage of gross income
glossary.PITH: Principal, Interest, Taxes, Heating (and 50% condo fees)
glossary.LTV: Loan-to-Value - Mortgage amount as percentage of property value
glossary.MQR: Mortgage Qualifying Rate - Rate used for stress test qualification
glossary.OSFI: Office of the Superintendent of Financial Institutions
glossary.T4: Statement of Remuneration Paid (Canadian tax form)
glossary.NOA: Notice of Assessment from Canada Revenue Agency
glossary.HBP: Home Buyers' Plan - RRSP withdrawal program
glossary.FHSA: First Home Savings Account - Tax-advantaged savings for first-time buyers
glossary.FTHBI: First-Time Home Buyer Incentive - CMHC shared equity program
glossary.LTT: Land Transfer Tax - Provincial/municipal tax on property purchases
glossary.PTT: Property Transfer Tax - BC term for land transfer tax
glossary.FINTRAC: Financial Transactions and Reports Analysis Centre of Canada
glossary.CCA: Capital Cost Allowance (depreciation for tax purposes)
glossary.BFS: Business for Self - Self-employed mortgage program
